chunks.translated_text:
**The Returning Flame**

The Lord of Ju’s greed was hard to fathom,
Yet the pure and loyal King of Shu never doubted him.
A raging flame stretching to the heavens was truly fearsome,
But a mighty wind turned back upon its bearer brought peril.
A voice from the void spoke with perfect clarity—
Only then did they believe the gods could not be deceived.

King Yuliang of Shu had a younger brother, Jiameng, whom he enfeoffed at Ju, making him the Lord of Ju. Over time, Ju sent envoys demanding bribes, but the King of Shu refused. Thereupon, Ju dispatched men to burn Shu’s treasuries. The fire blazed fiercely. Upon hearing this, I commanded the Wind Master to reverse the flames, declaring aloud Ju’s treachery. In an instant, all Ju’s messengers perished in the fire. From then on, Ju and Shu waged war for three years, yet Ju could never overcome Shu.

**Chapter Forty-Three: Pacifying Ju**

The Lord of Ju established his state as Jiameng,
Forgetting that Yufu was his own brother.
Weapons clashed, and the people died unjustly,
While neighboring borders vied in vain.
Then, through envoys, the situation was discussed—
Divine soldiers appeared to show the weight of heaven’s will.
Once the people of Jia realized righteousness,
They spared the common folk from suffering.

After Ju and Shu had long been at odds, the King of Shu grew weary of war and sent Zhuang Su to negotiate peace. The Lord of Ju refused. Zhuang Su then spoke of Shu’s military strength, pointing toward the western frontier. I manifested divine soldiers to warn him. Suspecting an ambush, the Lord of Ju sought a truce. His envoys reported this to the king, who then built a temple for me north of the capital.

**Chapter Forty-Four: Fei Ding**

Though he upheld the straight path in life, he met with misfortune,
His lingering spirit after death scorned empty flattery.
The king favored the Five Ding, forgetting military preparedness—
I, in turn, opposed them with the might of the Three Di.
Obsessed with piling earth to honor his concubine’s tomb,
He scorned talk of war and rejected defense of the frontier.
“What care I for your ominous words?” he sneered,
Then destroyed my temple—what harm could that do?

A mountain spirit from Wudu transformed into a woman, surpassingly beautiful, the like of which had never been seen in Shu. King Kaiming Shang of Shu saw her and was captivated, taking her as his concubine. Soon after, she died, and the king mourned her endlessly. He ordered her tomb built ever higher to show his undying devotion. The five Fei brothers of Wudu, men of great strength, curried favor with the king. Using their might, they hauled earth from Wudu Mountain to raise the tomb, and in no time, the mound rivaled the mountain’s height. The king named it Wukai Mountain, saying the concubine’s death had moved the earth.

Thereafter, the king trusted and favored the Five Ding, keeping them constantly by his side. He himself was strong and proud of his prowess. With the Five Ding at his command, he boasted that his bare hands could break spears and halberds, that his fleet feet could outrun chariots and cavalry. Thus, he neglected border defenses, dismantling outposts and extinguishing beacons.

As I was now his tutelary deity, receiving his sacrifices, and with mighty Qin on his borders, I feared the unforeseen. I transformed into a scholar, calling myself Zhang Sheng of the Northern Capital, and knocked at the palace gates to submit a memorial. Its gist was this:

*“I have heard that those who rely on virtue prosper, while those who rely on force perish. In the governance of Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang, the ministers at court were known by name, yet none relied solely on strength. Mere personal bravery cannot be depended upon, nor can exceptional skill overawe enemies. Fei Lian and E Lai could not save King Zhou of Shang, nor could Hou Yi and Ao escape violent deaths. In recent times, the Three Di, though tall and mighty, were ultimately exterminated.*

*Now, the five Fei brothers at the frontier possess no virtue, only brute strength. The king, impressed by their size and might, has neglected military preparedness. I say that the strength of the Fei brothers may equal ten men, even a hundred, but if used against an enemy, it will be of no avail. If stationed on watchtowers or employed as charioteers, their bare arms and legs wielding bows and reins, running to serve—this is acceptable. But to rely on them to repel neighboring states is folly. In truth, they are no different from the Red, White, or Long Di of old.*

*I urge you to cherish the foundations laid by your ancestors and strengthen border defenses against Qin. Do not let the bravado of a few men undermine the discipline of the Three Armies.”*

The king was displeased: *“You urge me to tighten military preparedness yet mock my nurturing of talented warriors. It is like hunting without hawks or guarding against thieves without dogs.”*

I argued vehemently, but the Five Ding, basking in the king’s favor, sought to humiliate me. I vanished from their sight. The Five Ding declared me a demon and said, *“This must be Zhang Zhongzi of the Northern Suburbs.”* They then destroyed my temple, but I paid it no mind.

**Chapter Forty-Five: The Stone Oxen**

Shu and Ba clashed—Shu was rich and strong,
Qin coveted Shu and schemed cunningly.
Not that King Hui devised a wise plan,
But that Kaiming’s folly led him astray.
Stone oxen stood at the mountain’s foot,
Molten gold hidden beneath their tails.
Greed blinded him to loyal ministers’ counsel—
Carving roads and raising armies brought later calamity.

As the Zhou house declined, the feudal lords encroached upon one another. Ba and Shu fell into conflict, and Qin, bordering Shu, plotted to annex it. King Hui of Qin followed the strategy of Sima Cuo, but the Shu roads were perilously steep, leaving no path for an army. Thus, at the Qin-Shu border, they carved five stone oxen, each of colossal size, and placed them in the grass. They also cast gold into cakes and hid them beneath the oxen’s tails. Spies were sent to observe. After a month, the gold cakes were taken, only to be replaced. As the thefts grew frequent, the King of Shu learned of it. He sent men to investigate and, over months, amassed over a thousand catties of gold.

He then ordered the Five Ding to carve a treacherous path, leading five thousand soldiers to haul the stone oxen back. On the day they set out, I once more transformed, this time into a scholar named Zhonggong Zichang, and sought an audience at court. I submitted a memorial, warning that opening the road was unwise and that the gold was a snare. The king laughed and said:

*“Heaven does not begrudge the Dao, nor earth its treasures. By the grace of the altars of soil and grain, stone oxen and yellow gold have entered my realm. Gold is the most precious of treasures—it can enrich the state, strengthen the army, and ease the people’s burdens. You suspect deceit from a neighboring state—this is overcaution. Who would cast away thousands of gold to set a trap?”*

I raised my face to heaven and cried out, shedding tears in streams. The king deemed me an ill omen, and his attendants dragged me out. I then withdrew into concealment.

**Five Wives (Forty-Sixth)**
The Qin, greedy for Shu’s land, schemed to swallow it whole;
A treacherous path was carved, opening Shu’s gates wide.
Yet still they feared the stone oxen might expose their ruse,
So offered royal daughters to seal the bond anew.
They never reckoned a great state makes a perilous match,
Assuming only sincerity lay behind the vow.
Though I knew my words of warning would be spurned as waste,
How could I bear silence and betray my lord’s trust?

Once the stone oxen were brought back, the King of Qin said: *“This stratagem served well to open the road, but if the oxen return without gold, my plan is undone.”* He then sent envoys to propose a marriage alliance with Shu, declaring: *“Qin and Shu are neighbors—kinship and goodwill between neighbors are the natural order. I have five daughters of royal blood; I ask that the King of Shu accept them as brides.”*

The King of Shu rejoiced greatly. Upon hearing this, I sighed and said: *“That is a mighty state—how could such a thing be fitting for us?”* The king dispatched the Five Ding to the border to receive the Qin princesses. He himself prepared a thousand chariots and waited at the northern outskirts, eager to glimpse their faces.

I then appeared among the guards in the guise of a scholar, stepped forward, and submitted a memorial in protest. The king grew furious: *“Are you not that meddlesome Zhang Zhongzi of Beiguo? This is the third time your slanderous words have shamed me!”* He ordered his attendants to seize me. I revealed my wrathful aspect, and the guards scattered in terror. Thus I escaped.

**Manifesting the Divine (Forty-Seventh)**
My loyal heart could not endure Qin’s encroachment on Shu;
Though I remonstrated with all my strength, my lord spurned me.
My fierce mien was meant to strike fear into the enemy,
Yet in an instant, my great form vanished, concealed by jade decree.
The winding path of seven bends was just traversed,
When mountains crushed the host of spirits—all perished in the end.
From that time on, this corner of the land knew reverence,
And the might of Jiannan blazed like fire.

After the Five Ding escorted the Qin princesses back, the people of Shu—from the lowliest to the highest—rejoiced, blind to the snare of disaster. They mistook peril for fortune, mourning for celebration—such is the common folly of the multitude.

I then manifested my colossal form upon the southern slope of Jianling, blocking the road, hoping the Qin princesses would turn back in fear. The people of Qin and Shu who witnessed this were struck with awe. Amid the clamor of weapons and the din of chariots, a jade-like voice resounded, saying: *“What Heaven has doomed cannot be revived—such is the King of Shu. What Heaven has destined to rise cannot be thwarted—such is the King of Qin. You are truly loyal, but what can loyalty do against Heaven’s decree?”* I then withdrew.

The Five Ding recognized me and cried: *“This must be the Beiguo spirit Zhang Zhongzi!”* They sought to seize and devour me. The clamor of the multitude shook the mountains and rivers. The Five Ding pursued me as I fled through the heart of the mountain, carving a path of seven winding turns. As I neared a cave, they overtook me and seized me with force. I had no choice but to expand my form a hundredfold, allowing them to tug and drag me. Soon, my head pierced the mountain’s summit. I turned my radiance back to gaze upon them, shaking the earth with my power—the mountain trembled in response. The Five Ding and the Qin princesses were swept beneath the cliffs as the mountain collapsed with terrifying speed. Thus, the Five Ding and the Five Wives were all buried beneath the land. Thereafter, Shu was annexed by Qin, and I bore no further regret.

**Great Elixir (Forty-Eighth)**
The Old Master wearied of war in the Central Plains,
And journeyed west to compose the *Huahu Jing*.

Amid the clouds, chariots and cavalry stretched a thousand li,
Wherever I passed, spirits and deities escorted me ten stages on.
The heart of impartiality dissolved the grievance of slain lives,
Swallowing the elixir, the resolve of the body grew light as one.

The Qian direction was no place to conceal myself,
So I dwelt in the Kun corner to console the multitudes.
After Shu’s fall, its altars and temples were overturned,
The hundred spirits abandoned their sacrifices, their blood-offerings left unclaimed.
I wandered to Kongtong, seeking respite for a time.

Suddenly, within the cloud-laden thoroughfare, banners, pennants, chariots, and cavalry passed for three days.
The mountain spirits remarked to one another: “Such a spectacle—surely a sage or worthy is passing through.”
Soon after, the Old Master, accompanied by the Two Perfected Ones of Left and Right, journeyed from east to west.
I joined the ranks, bowing among the earth deities of the Western Marchmount’s domain.
The Western Marchmount issued a decree: all earth deities bowed and escorted them ten stages.
I remained among the protective retinue for several days.

One day, I earnestly entreated the Old Master,
And the Perfected One recounted my past merits and faults in Shu.
The Old Master said: “When the Great Dao prevails, the world is held in common.
Since your heart was impartial, and you remonstrated thrice with Shu—this was your merit.
Though the Five Ding and Five Wives perished by your hand, your heart held to impartiality, so it was no fault.
Though you rendered service to Shu, now the state bears the name of Qin, yet its towns and villages remain Shu’s.
You should forever receive Shu’s sacrifices to console its people.”

Thereupon, he commanded Xu Jia to take a single grain of medicine from his pouch and bestow it upon me, saying:
“This is the Great Elixir. You should ingest it.
In its fullness, it unites with the Dao as truth; as an elixir, it merges with the heart as one.
Thereafter, your five penetrations will be complete—unlike your former self.
The Central Plains are in turmoil, and I weary of it.
Now I shall enter the Western Regions to transform the lands.
Three hundred years hence, the teachings of the West will flourish and come to the Middle Kingdom.
You should have faith in them.”
I reverently received his words.

chunks.original_text: 大凡临事莫欺心，心镜才昏祸即侵。 巧计受珠夸幸械，厉声决狱逞胸襟。 鞭笞二百难轻恕，受痛三旬可自斟。 庙貌焚修非所望，祇将直道报知音。 秦既并蜀，使张仪虏巴王而取其地，因以巴都为郡。 久之，巴都守相伊庭仪，以太守疾摄事，郡民张威家奴万真，投井而死，狱威月余，威不任棰楚，诬服曰，实威杀而投之，盖万真先有所犯，威尝挞之，不三日，真窃其赀，欲逃他所，为威所觉，真臆度不免，乃自尽其命，实非威杀之也。 狱成，威之子闻之，以大珠百枚，遣人献於庭仪，庭仪谓用事者曰：汝医者，别日但以小箧作风药来，虽在客前，无忸怩也，其家甚喜。 至日，候门献之，庭仪适会客十余，方具酒肴，医者至，且延之坐末，三行，医起以献药为言，伊受之，方入中溜，旋悔之曰：事有不明，恐招谤议，命出之，封提如故，伊复命医者，开箧取药，犹恐事泄，分献众客，翌日以威之欵伏辜，卒陷大辟。 威之子行哭於市，仰天呼冤曰：还有神灵察此冤抑否？ 予见之，夜迎庭仪及威之父子，医者魂爽诉之得情，庭仪曰：珠实某取之，箧中之药，乃素所备者，珠方入而易之，既受其珠，复畏太守知之，故不敢易其欵，予命鞭庭仪背二百，明日所讯之人寤，言皆同，方共讶之，俄闻庭仪疽发於背，号呼月余乃死。 威之家为予立庙，一郡之人，从而见敬。 婆娑第五十
chunks.translated_text:
In all affairs, never deceive the heart—
when the heart’s mirror dims, calamity soon invades.
Cunning schemes to accept pearls, boasting of luck in restraint,
harsh verdicts in court, flaunting one’s resolve.
Two hundred lashes may not lightly be pardoned,
yet enduring pain for thirty days is for one to weigh.
Temple rites and offerings were never my desire—
only to repay with uprightness those who know my heart.

After Qin annexed Shu, it sent Zhang Yi to capture the King of Ba and seize his lands, thereafter establishing Ba Capital as a commandery. Some time later, Yi Tingyi, the governor of Ba Capital, fell ill, and the commandery’s administrator took charge of affairs. A slave of the commoner Zhang Wei, named Wanzhen, threw himself into a well and died. The case dragged on for over a month, and Wei, unable to endure the flogging, falsely confessed: “It was I who killed him and cast him in.” In truth, Wanzhen had earlier committed some offense, and Wei had once beaten him. Within three days, Wanzhen stole Wei’s valuables, intending to flee elsewhere, but was discovered by Wei. Fearing he could not escape punishment, Wanzhen took his own life—it was not Wei who killed him.

When the verdict was reached, Wei’s son heard of it and sent someone to present Yi Tingyi with a hundred large pearls. Tingyi said to his attendant: “You, the physician, on another day bring only a small box of medicinal powder. Even in the presence of guests, do not act ashamed.” The family was overjoyed. On the appointed day, they waited at the gate to present it. Tingyi happened to be entertaining over ten guests, wine and dishes already laid out, when the physician arrived. He was invited to sit at the end of the table. After three rounds of drinking, the physician rose and spoke of presenting the medicine. Tingyi accepted it, but as soon as it was taken inside, he regretted it, saying: “The matter is unclear, and I fear slanderous talk.” He ordered it brought out again, still sealed as before. Then he commanded the physician to open the box and take out the medicine, yet still anxious that word might leak, he divided it among all the guests. The next day, Wei’s forced confession was upheld, and he was ultimately sentenced to execution.

Wei’s son wailed in the marketplace, looking to the heavens and crying out: “Is there no divine spirit to examine this injustice?” I witnessed this and that night summoned the souls of Tingyi, Wei and his son, and the physician, who revealed the truth. Tingyi said: “The pearls were indeed taken by me. The medicine in the box was something I had long prepared. I had just accepted the pearls when I changed my mind. Though I took them, I feared the governor would learn of it, so I dared not alter the verdict.” I ordered Tingyi’s back to be flogged two hundred times. The next day, the interrogated man awoke and gave the same account as before. All were astonished, but soon after, Tingyi developed an abscess on his back. He howled in agony for over a month before dying.

Wei’s family built a temple for me, and the people of the entire commandery came to revere it.

**Posa (Fiftieth)**

A child’s birth demands reverence for parents,
From infancy they toil to raise your frame.
To claim another’s name should bring you shame—
How could you cast aside the ones who bore you, though poor they remain?
In office, punished—suffering hard to bear;
In dreams, the lash falls—pain the same, no less.
Yet once injustice binds them as father and son,
Can the customs of our homeland return to their purest dress?

Within the borders of the two commanderies of Ba and Shu, there stands a mountain called Posa. The mountain spirit Yuan Anxing came to the waters of Yu in Ba Commandery and addressed me, saying: “In the lands I govern, the people are diligent and trustworthy, filial toward their ancestors to the utmost, and reverent toward spirits and gods. In matters great or small, they divine with tortoise and milfoil—only if the omens are auspicious do they dare to act. The Mountain King once ruled all the spirits of Shu. Now Ba, Shu, Qian, and Han are divided into four commanderies, though the Qin regard them all as one, calling them Shu. In the lands I govern, why does the King not deign to visit?”

I, considering it not an official matter, did not wish to go lightly. One day, Anxing came again and said: “In my domain, there is a man named Zhou Fu, originally the son of the Yuan clan—a kinsman of mine. He abandoned his carriage to follow the Yuans, as custom simplifies the name.”

chunks.original_text: 符之生日时皆恶，乃祖忌之，命勿举，其父平叔不忍弃，乳养于外，三岁正旦，拜诸孙中，翁乃大怒，诟其子曰：汝欲以此命凶之子杀我耶？ 平叔提携而出。 适友人周宁之相遇於途，且告之故，宁之曰：我未有后人，今请养之，他日，吾室有所出，则还君之姓，平叔与之。 自后周日益富，袁以家祸连绵，贫甚，及周有子，而前约不复讲矣。 宁之既亡，平叔时往访符，或告之急，则亦相济至于数四，平叔私许以为符实己子，且尝念我，乘间为符言其始末，会符之弟来，适闻平叔之语，叱平叔出，明日投牒於官，以平叔之言不直，笞之，平叔灶香于顶，以告於安行，且言子敢笞父，安行知其详，念非符本心，未有所裁，王为央之。 予乃与安行偕往，夜梦於符，见己之初生及王父不举之语，及乃亲乳养之事，梦未毕，哭而起，欲自庾，又以形於公牍牵制於弟，隐忍间，予复梦中责其不即听从，笞之百下，符既觉，达旦不寐，明日拜于袁氏之门，谓平叔曰：符不早悟，为大人遗体，令神来见责，挞我几死，今悔矣，且周氏自有子可承祭祀，符已不愿预其家产，唯吾父之从。 乡人知之，以符为贤，周之子筮乃分家赏与符，任其归宗，袁之夫妇老且有托焉。 梓潼帝君化书卷之二竟 #1『玉心』，疑为『王心』之误。 #2『一万』，疑为『一方』之误。 梓潼帝君化书卷之三 戒龙第五十一
chunks.translated_text:
Zhou Fu’s birth date and hour were both inauspicious, so his grandfather forbade raising him. His father, Pingshu, could not bear to abandon him and had him nursed in secret outside the home. On New Year’s Day when he was three, he was brought before the grandchildren to pay respects. The old man flew into a rage and berated his son: “Do you mean to kill me with this ill-omened child?” Pingshu carried him out at once.

They happened to meet a friend, Zhou Ningzhi, on the road. Pingshu told him the story, and Ningzhi said: “I have no heir. Let me raise him. If one day my wife bears a son, I will return him to your family.” Pingshu agreed. Thereafter, the Zhous grew ever wealthier, while the Yuans suffered one misfortune after another and fell into dire poverty. When the Zhous had a son of their own, they no longer spoke of the earlier promise.

After Ningzhi died, Pingshu would visit Fu from time to time. If Fu was in urgent need, Pingshu would help him repeatedly. Pingshu privately believed Fu was truly his own son and had not forgotten him. When an opportunity arose, he told Fu the whole story. Just then, Fu’s younger brother arrived and overheard Pingshu’s words. He drove Pingshu out, and the next day filed a complaint with the authorities, accusing Pingshu of falsehood. Pingshu was flogged. He burned incense on his head and reported the matter to Anxing, saying: “My son dares to flog his father.”

Anxing knew the details and realized this was not Fu’s true intention, but he had not yet decided what to do when the King intervened on Pingshu’s behalf. I then went with Anxing to visit Fu. That night, I dreamed of Fu, seeing the circumstances of his birth, his grandfather’s refusal to raise him, and how his own father had nursed and reared him. Before the dream ended, I awoke in tears, wishing to take my own life. But I was bound by the official records and constrained by his younger brother, so I endured in silence.

That night, I dreamed again, rebuking Fu for not immediately obeying and flogging him a hundred times. When Fu awoke, he could not sleep until dawn. The next day, he went to the Yuan household and said to Pingshu: “I was slow to understand. As your own flesh and blood, I have now been rebuked by the gods, who nearly flogged me to death. I repent. Moreover, the Zhous have a son to continue their ancestral sacrifices, and I no longer wish to share in their family property. I only desire to follow my father.”

The villagers, learning of this, praised Fu as virtuous. The Zhous’ son divined and decided to divide the family property, giving a share to Fu and allowing him to return to his original clan. The Yuan couple, now old, had someone to rely on at last.

chunks.original_text: 周既为秦九鼎迁，诸龙听命海神前。 辄因争道宣余忿，不顾殃民有重愆。 指石为盟心可信，仰天设誓语无偏。 从兹岸浒耕桑者，无复横流浸渍年。 青衣之水，自西而东，与岷江相会，秦既并周，九鼎西迁，诸山之祇会于岳灵，诸川之龙朝于海若，所以听革命而效灵祉也。 二龙俱东，相值于江，合之中流，争先以行，气不相下，斗於江渊，二水俱壅，波涛横涌，民居其浒者，千有余家，一日浸渍，奔避无及，怨苦之声，达于四境。 予适见之，先遣阴兵万众，障其狂波，予造水中解纷，谓之曰：维新之命，易我旧德，余忿不忘，百灵皆然，何独二君？ 今以争道而斗，祸及居人，向非吾兵障流，则此邑之民，靡有孑遗矣。 且上帝好生，后悔何及。 二龙曰：敬受教令，既遣俱行，且约归而成之，及朝宗回日，予与之尸事，仰天设誓，指东西二大石，叱之使起，须臾两石峙而立。 予复戒之曰：二江之龙，言归于好，天地为质，斯言不渝，若二石合而为一，则今日之盟可寒，决别而退。 凤山第五十二 千重肌肉受胞胎，十月怀耽岂易哉。 情实片言违主意，羁栖两纪受身灾。 不因梦里腾魂出，争得山边避雨来。 子母如初天理在，晚年甘旨且相陪。 果山之隅，富人王基，五旬无子，一日醉饱形言，睨其妻曰：人之欲富者，生有衣食之养，死有祭祀之归也，今富而无子，安用富为哉？ 妻安氏亦巨室也，生平不字，性严而妬，闻以自愧，乃出妆资，买柳氏女以奉良人，逾年有娠，安喜甚，旦夜焚香，祝于天地，每以王氏嗣续为请。 知柳有娠，即以己之衣饰与之，至於防护饮食寝处，无不经意，临蓐之月，前期择女医以为备，既分免，果得男子，大喜。 儿之乳哺褪褓，大小便利，皆自洗濯，视其子犹己生也。 夫君贤之，子百晬，名曰宜寿，亦安之意也。 寻别召乳妇专饲养之。 或语柳曰：吾与汝主客也，汝至吾家，饮食受用，与吾无异，盖以吾儿之故，尔儿将周晬矣，吾将择媒嫁汝为良人妻也。 柳乃号泣曰：非所愿也，愿与宜寿相处，死而后已，安不悦曰：汝欲与我为代耶？ 寻挞之，即易其衣装，食以粗粝，视之如犬豕，呼则以畜名之，力则辛苦毕责於柳。 宜寿三岁，一日走投柳怀，相向而泣，柳曰：我以儿故，饥寒苦力无所恨也，迩来月余不见儿面，儿忆母否？ 宜寿亦哭之，声闻于外，安往视之，夺儿出，持挺棰之甚苦，时当寒月，尽褫其衣，夜屏之外，诘早，呼里胥而逐之。 基以重伤宜寿之心，劝留之，安曰：我与此畜势不俱存，今欲以此畜为妻，则我且出，必欲留我，则无容此畜，傥移时而不决，则我且求死於君前，基不能拒，与柳所服裙钗，俾携而为赀，安氏夺之。 柳以久於饥困，憔悴骨立，鬓发童秃，身肉枯黑，人无取焉，乃行於城郭，窘食自养，适王之族有徙居通川者，挈柳偕行，年余，安知之，贻书诟责，又被逐焉。 既无所向，乃以薪水力作，糊口於人。 厥后两周星纪，宜寿父母皆死，己亦有子十岁，名知微，或告其妻康氏曰：我家生理颇丰，诸无不足，惟我所生，不知存殁，日夜愁苦，我今三十，而已华发，伊此故也。 即以家务委其妻曰：善视吾子，我将访母，见而后归。 乃出而北行，凡遇井邑，触处徘徊，淹留道涂。
chunks.translated_text:
When the Zhou lost the Nine Tripods to Qin and they were moved away,
All dragons heeded the Sea God’s command before him.
Yet in their struggle for precedence they vented their lingering wrath,
Heedless of the calamity they brought upon the people, a grave transgression.
Pointing to stone they swore an oath they could trust,
Looking to heaven they pledged their words without bias.
From then on, those who tilled and wove along the riverbanks
No longer suffered the yearly ravages of flooding.

The waters of the Qingyi flowed from west to east,
Meeting the Min River where they converged.
When Qin conquered Zhou and the Nine Tripods were moved west,
The spirits of the mountains gathered at the sacred peaks,
And the dragons of the rivers paid homage to the Sea God,
Thus obeying the mandate of revolution and offering their numinous blessings.
Two dragons, both heading east, met in the river,
Converging at its center, each vying to go first.
Neither would yield in their struggle,
Battling in the river’s depths.
The two waters surged, waves and billows raging,
Flooding the homes of over a thousand families along the banks.
In a single day, the waters rose, leaving no time to flee.
The cries of suffering reached the four corners of the land.

I happened to witness this and first dispatched a host of ten thousand spirit soldiers
To block the raging waves.
Then I entered the water to mediate their dispute, saying:
“The mandate of renewal has replaced my former virtue,
Yet lingering resentment remains—all spirits feel this.
Why should you two alone be different?
Now, in your struggle for precedence, you have brought disaster upon the people.
Had my soldiers not blocked the flood,
Not a single soul in this town would have survived.
Moreover, the August Supreme favors life—what use is regret once harm is done?”

The two dragons replied: “We respectfully accept your command.
Since we were both sent forth, let us now make a pact to resolve this.
When we return from paying homage to the sea,
We will entrust the matter to you.”
Looking to heaven, they swore an oath,
Pointing to two great stones, east and west, and commanding them to rise.
In an instant, the two stones stood upright.
I then admonished them: “The dragons of the two rivers have reconciled,
With heaven and earth as their witness.
This vow must not be broken.
If these two stones ever merge into one,
Then today’s oath will be rendered void.”
With that, they parted and withdrew.

**Admonition to the Phoenix Mountain Fifty-Second**

Through a thousand layers of flesh she bore the womb’s burden,
Ten months of pregnancy—how could it be easy?
A single word against her master’s will,
And for twelve years she endured the torment of exile in her own body.
Had her soul not soared in dreams,
How could she have found shelter by the mountain to escape the storm?
Mother and child reunited as before—heaven’s principle endures,
In her later years, she enjoyed the sweetness of filial care.

At the edge of Guoshan,
A wealthy man named Wang Ji, fifty years old and childless,
Once, after drinking and feasting to excess, glanced at his wife and said:
“People desire wealth to ensure sustenance in life and ancestral sacrifices after death.
Now, though I am rich, I have no son—what use is wealth to me?”
His wife, Lady An, also from a prominent family, had never borne children.
Proud and jealous by nature, she felt ashamed upon hearing this.
She took her jewelry and dowry, bought a girl from the Liu family,
And presented her to her husband.
A year later, the girl conceived.
Lady An rejoiced, burning incense day and night,
Praying to heaven and earth, beseeching for an heir to the Wang lineage.
When she learned of Liu’s pregnancy,
She gave the girl her own clothes and ornaments.
In matters of diet, rest, and care, she spared no effort.
In the month before the birth, she prepared in advance, selecting a midwife.
When the time came, a son was born.
Overjoyed, she personally tended to the child’s nursing, swaddling,
And even washed his diapers and cleaned him after bowel movements,
Treating him as if he were her own.
Her husband praised her virtue.
When the child turned one hundred days old, they named him Yishou,
A name reflecting Lady An’s wishes.
Soon after, they hired a wet nurse to care for him exclusively.

Some said to Liu: “You and I are host and guest in this household.
Since you arrived, you have enjoyed the same food and comforts as I.
Now, because of my son, your child is nearly a year old.
I will arrange a matchmaker to marry you to a good man.”
Liu wept bitterly and said: “That is not my wish.
I only desire to stay with Yishou until death.”
Lady An, displeased, said: “Do you seek to replace me?”
She soon beat Liu, stripped her of fine clothes,
Gave her coarse food, and treated her like a beast,
Calling her by the names of livestock.
All hard labor was forced upon Liu.

When Yishou was three years old,
One day, he ran into Liu’s arms, and they wept together.
Liu said: “For your sake, I endure hunger, cold, and toil without complaint.
But for over a month, I have not seen you—do you miss your mother?”
Yishou wept as well, his cries heard outside.
Lady An rushed in, snatched the child away,
And beat him severely.
It was a cold month, and she stripped him of his clothes,
Banishing him outside for the night.
At dawn, she summoned the village elder and expelled Liu.
Wang Ji, grieved by the harm done to Yishou’s heart, urged her to stay.
Lady An said: “I cannot coexist with this beast.
If you wish to make her your wife, I will leave.
If you want to keep me, she cannot stay.
If you delay in deciding, I will seek death before you.”
Unable to refuse, Wang Ji gave Liu the skirt and hairpins she had worn,
Allowing her to take them as provisions.
But Lady An seized them back.

After enduring prolonged hunger and hardship,
Liu became emaciated, her hair falling out, her skin dark and withered.
No one would take her in.
She wandered the city, barely sustaining herself,
Until Wang’s relatives, who were moving to Tongchuan, took her along.
A year later, Lady An learned of this and sent a letter filled with abuse,
Driving her away again.
With nowhere to go, Liu resorted to gathering firewood and drawing water,
Earning a meager living from others.

Twelve years passed.

Someone told his wife, Lady Kang: “Our household is prosperous,
Lacking nothing—except knowledge of my birth mother’s fate.
Day and night, I grieve, and at thirty, my hair has turned gray—all because of this.”
He entrusted his household affairs to his wife, saying:
“Take good care of our son. I will seek my mother and return only after I find her.”
He set out northward, lingering in every town and village along the way,
His journey prolonged by his search.

chunks.original_text: 俄尔经岁，宜寿每出行路，哀哭摧毁，日惟一饭，菜米而已，诚动幽明，所至祇灵为之感格。 巴梁二江相合之地，有凤凰山，予徜徉焉，见一老妪负薪行烈日中，挥汗不已，憩於松下，南向长号曰：宜寿、宜寿，吾儿健否？ 母困极於此，儿安得而念之。 予闻之有所不忍，呼里域独孤正而询之，正曰：是王宜寿之所生母也。 时宜寿久外，其家促归，已返中涂，予为梦之，宜寿自见所生在家之日，苦乐之详，及路中相见之处，明日大喜曰：神明告我，子母相见有兆矣。 乃复北首，所经山川道里，皆梦中境也，行三日，到凤山之下，方炊，暴雨忽至，行人莫进，良久，一村妇负薪而入，见宜寿揖之，宜寿心动，询之，乃其母也，迎而归之，柳年八十而卒。 鱼腹第五十三 生身为女已卑微，况被狂夫掠卖之。

She rested beneath a pine, facing south, and wailed: *"Yishou, Yishou—is my son well? I suffer here in exhaustion, yet how could he ever think of me?"*

Moved by what he could not bear to hear, he called to a local man, Dugu Zheng, and asked about her. Zheng replied: *"That is the birth mother of Wang Yishou."*

By then, Yishou had been away for so long that his family urged his return. The next day, overjoyed, he declared: *"The gods have shown me! There is an omen that mother and son shall meet."*

As he prepared a meal, a sudden downpour forced travelers to halt. After some time, a village woman entered, carrying firewood. When Yishou saw her and bowed, his heart stirred. chunks.original_text: 饮泣父亲成瞽废，积忧母氏似迷痴。 异乡苦乐诚难测，一命存亡不可知。 直待咎元彰报应，临终方悔得便宜。 蜀土之生民，二男四女，故其俗以女为卑。 涪水之源，富民任盈年老无嗣，惟一女，爱之，名宝珠，年十五，随邻伴遨游蚕市，灯下稠人中迷路，为恶少昝元诱之，父母重赏寻访月余，已为元所卖於夔子矣，父哭之失明，母义氏心气成健忘。 如此十年，百计求之，了无音耗，盈闻七曲之灵，乃肘行膝步，号泣见投，愿一见珠而死。 予闵之，乃敕八功曹将三百阴兵，方圆千里四外求之，或见珠於夔之鱼腹，负汲而哀，询之瀼龙，乃得其实。 予乃夜梦於盈，自七曲而南，沿流下之，直抵夔门，见女与语，女亦梦见其父，既明，盈谢而去，使人相之，盖如梦中所行，乃见焉。 珠初为人婢，主母恶之，而棰挞过甚，又转他家，前主倍取其佣，又三年，复为邻子诈欺曰：尔父求汝，令我与汝来，又转之他家，如此前后四主矣。 珠今在张白家，主母忌人有孕，而珠实怀之，恐得罪，欲赴於江。 而如有人难之，父闻珠声音，目乃有见，俱诣其主，赎身以归，母亦疾愈。 昝元者老矣，予乃遣功曹监治之，日挞三百，凡月余，抉其两目，乞丐於市，自陈曰：宝珠之失身，元之罪也，今为七曲张主治我良苦且死矣，逾年而殂。 口业第五十四 人生口业报非轻，莫把邪言作课程。
chunks.translated_text:
Weeping, her father was blinded by grief;
Her mother, consumed by sorrow, seemed lost in madness.
In a foreign land, joys and sorrows are truly hard to fathom—
A single life’s survival or ruin remains unknown.
Only when retribution for past wrongs is made manifest
Does one, on the brink of death, regret having taken advantage.

Among the people of Shu, two sons and four daughters were born,
Yet their customs deemed daughters lowly.
At the source of the Fu River, a wealthy man named Ren Ying, old and without heirs,
Had but one daughter, whom he cherished—named Baozhu.
At fifteen, she wandered the silkworm market with neighbors,
And in the lantern-lit crowd, lost her way.
A rogue named Zan Yuan lured her away.
Her parents offered a great reward and searched for over a month,
Only to find she had already been sold by Yuan to a man in Kuizhou.
Her father wept until he lost his sight;
Her mother, Lady Yi, fell into a forgetful stupor from grief.

For ten years, they sought her by every means,
Yet heard not a whisper of her fate.
Ying, having heard of the numinous power of Sevenfold Curve,
Crawled on elbows and knees, wailing as he made his plea,
Begging to see his daughter once before he died.
Moved by his plight, I commanded the Eight Divine Clerks
To dispatch three hundred spirit soldiers,
Searching a thousand *li* in every direction.
One day, they saw Baozhu in Kuizhou’s Fish Belly,
Carrying water and weeping in sorrow.
They inquired of the Rang Dragon and learned the truth.

That night, I appeared to Ying in a dream:
From Sevenfold Curve southward, following the current,
He would reach Kuimen, where he would find his daughter and speak with her.
Baozhu, too, dreamed of her father.
At dawn, Ying gave thanks and departed.
He sent men to follow the path from his dream—
And there she was.

Baozhu had first been a servant,
But her mistress despised her and beat her cruelly.
She was then sold to another household,
Where her former master demanded double her wages.
Three years later, a neighbor’s son deceived her, saying,
*"Your father seeks you. He sent me to bring you."*
Thus, she was sold again—
This was her fourth master.
Now, Baozhu was in the household of Zhang Bai.
Her mistress loathed pregnant women,
And Baozhu, truly with child, feared punishment
And sought to throw herself into the river.
But someone intervened.
When her father heard Baozhu’s voice, his eyes regained sight.
Together, they went to her master, ransomed her, and returned home.
Her mother’s illness, too, was cured.

Zan Yuan had grown old.
I sent the Divine Clerks to oversee his punishment:
Three hundred lashes a day for over a month,
Until his eyes were gouged out.
He begged in the marketplace, confessing,
*"Baozhu’s ruin was my sin.
Now, the master of Sevenfold Curve has tormented me near to death."*
A year later, he perished.

**Mouth-Karma Fifty-Four**
The retribution for mouth-karma in life is no light matter—
Never make wicked words your daily lesson.

chunks.original_text: 妄语以虚为实事，绮辞增百作千名。 血随砭石流无已，罪积阴司贯已盈。 犁舌不须求地狱，眼前公案甚分明。 龟城之民祝期生，有口才而习下人，有生相不具者讥笑之，妍美者亦疵毁之，愚昧者轻侮之，智能者亦评品之，贫者鄙薄之，富者亦讪谤之，官僚则播其阴私，士友则发其隐曲，至有门地才具出己之右，无可议论者，则曰乃祖微人也，乃父鄙人也，或曰其母家工商也，其妻家驵侩也，或曰厥弟不良也，厥子不肖也，凡所知识，皆不逃於贬刺之中。 此犹细故也，人小有过恶，则既传扬之，又增饰之，以无为有，以一为十，以疑似为端的，以偶然为故犯，以不得已为优为，以错误为情实，至於面折之，众辱之，又从而告讦之。 非特待他人如此，虽已之族党亦不兔焉，目其父母为顽嚣，目其兄弟为管蔡。 非止於身为之也，或教人兴讼，己则解释之，或教人诅骂，己则辩证之。 所习既久，不知其非，中年得舌黄之疾，使人砭刺出血，势少间，不数日，又作，寻复治之，大约一岁之问，疾五七作，每作不下出血一二升，率以为常。 一日，因与其徒话鬼神幽明之故，言天之雨阳之不时，地之丰歉之不一，鬼神之受人祭祀，祖弥之邀人奠醉，皆诃骂之。 予适与江渎会语，闻其多口，予方窃笑之，里域真官虞奇叔曰：此特万分之一耳，因备举而详言之，予乃遣功曹谬其操持，使自以手探舌出，以爪犁之，涎血淋漓，如屠狗彘，流溢於地，观者千百，使自宣其过曰：人之口业不可作也，如此月余，舌枯不能食而死。 东郭第五十五 工作虽然为得财，也须择术自量裁。

False speech turns emptiness into solid fact,
Flowery words swell hundreds into thousands in name.
Blood flows unceasing with the lancet’s sting,
While sins pile high in the Dark Bureau, their tally full.

No need to seek the Hell of the Plow-Tongue—
The case before your eyes is plainly clear.

The people of Tortoise City had one Zhu Qisheng,
A man of ready speech who curried favor with inferiors.
Those lacking in auspicious features he mocked,
The fair and comely he slandered.
The foolish he held in contempt,
The wise and capable he critiqued.
The poor he despised,
The rich he reviled.
Officials spread his private scandals,
Scholars and friends exposed his hidden faults.
Even those whose lineage, talent, or skill surpassed his own—
if no flaw could be found—
he would say, *"His grandfather was a lowly man,
his father a vulgar one,"*
or, *"His mother’s family were merchants,
his wife’s kin brokers."*
Or, *"His younger brother is no good,
his son unfilial."*
None he knew escaped his biting censure.

These were but trifling matters.
When someone committed even a minor wrong,
he would first spread the word,
then embellish it—
turning nothing into something,
one into ten,
suspicion into certainty,
accident into intent,
compulsion into willfulness,
error into truth.
He would confront them to their face,
humiliate them in public,
then drag their names through the mud.

Nor did he spare even his own kin:
his parents

chunks.original_text: 减轻添重由心造，提后推前以意猜。 业熟双眸皆瞽废，艺精五指尽伤摧。 三年阳责人为鉴，宁免鞭魂死后灾。 蜀郡土薄水浅，民生其间，率皆慧点有智数，多机变，巧於求利，阛阓之徒，虽一钱物皆有赝伪。 东郭人黎永正本攻轮舆，厌其作重而货迟，乃改业治斗甬，寻又治权衡，逾年，人有欲深斗重秤为嘱者，倍取其直而与之，其欲减勺为升，减合为斗，省铢为两，省两为斤者，亦如之。 永正又能作空中捩丝之秤，折底隆梁之斗，小民不顾报应者，以为便於日用，往往求之，一日，司察神紏奏，有旨：以为用之者固非，而作之者尤甚，俾所在神祇阳警而阴理之。 予乃遣里域神段彦梦挞永正，虽悟未悔。 既以声名渐彰，求者愈众，贪其工直，夜以继日，使其目力昏暗，以致蒙瞽，年方四十，妻弃而他之，二子生而亦盲。 又以久业於此，不欲顿废，既已失明，别无生理，乃至以手为目，揣摩广狭，臆度长短，锯斧钉钻，冒险施用，左手五指朝伤暮残，脓血甫乾，肌肤未平，寻复被苦指节零落，不能执持，行哭於市，人既识之，皆无所恤，饥寒切体，如此三年，使自暴白其过而死，二子相继以殍，由是所用之者，因少戢焉。 牛山第五十六 积善须逢善果圆，恶人还值恶因缘。 公平苟信无凶报，惨刻苏珍惹祸愆。 但种稻粱先满地，莫忧刑棘后参天。 诸君试看檐头水，滴滴相承不肯偏。 蜀郡涪郪二水相会旁有牛山，山之阿，井邑繁衍，邑之吏苟信、苏珍所居比邻，而每事相反，信以公恕，珍以深刻，信以廉节，珍以贪墨，信以惆傥，珍以阴谋，信以推诚无隐，珍以匿怨深中，信以语言必信，而不轻诺，珍以胁肩谄笑，而无情实，信奉母以孝，而教子以严，珍待父不敬，而纵妻犯上，信少求而俭用，珍奢费而无余，信和同上下而无怨言，珍以己律人而少许与，信掩人之过而省言，珍发人之私而多口。 乡里公私皆以信为贤，以珍为鄙，且忌珍之敢为而不能与之较。 岁终，邑人大集会，酒间，乡老周同举手示众曰：秦有二水，曰渭曰泾，一浊一清，皆赴于河，发源既殊，波荡不反，三尺童子见水之色，皆能以泾渭名之，盖以清浊取之也。 在人亦然。 方语未毕，珍乃面颈俱赤，投袂而起曰：苟君是渭、珍是泾矣，珍与苟信联事而切邻，珍之所为，惟信熟知，今信播扬珍恶，使乡老於广众中以水比喻，珍将报信以明心，信实未尝以告人也。 自尔，珍每见信必眦睚之，虽礼文相接，而中实仇敌也，又尝教其子明能伺苟之子仪真之便，且将杀之。 次年春，祈蚕行乐，明能与仪真并行江际，且语且笑，明能有恶心，而仪真未悟也，乃恃力推堕仪真水中，仪真急挽其衣与之俱坠，出没於浪花间。 予与诸龙君皆预供神之席，因勅二江龙拯之，郪涪二君雅知二子之详，乃携仪真近岸，而转明能于渊，会珍见之，褰裳而往，复取仪真挤焉，旋为仪真牵挽而入，观者如堵，呼哭腾沸。 予不平之，乃使郪龙曳珍之足沉焉，仪真得无恙，珍之父子皆溺，万人两两相谓曰：孰谓龙天八部有私乎？ 信与珍祸福不在於此日也，盖信之善果已熟，而珍之恶业方盈焉。 天威第五十七 妇人植性固多偏，孝养勤诚岂易全。 宿业虽应雷斧祸，今身幸有事亲缘。
chunks.translated_text:
The lightening or weighting springs from the heart’s design,
The delaying or advancing—mere guesswork of the mind.
When karma ripens, both eyes turn blind and waste away,
When skill is mastered, all five fingers break and fray.

Three years of yang-retribution serve as others’ mirror bright,
Yet how escape the lash of soul and postmortem blight?
In Shu’s thin soil and shallow streams,
the folk who dwell between
are sharp of wit and quick of scheme,
adept at profit’s art.
Even in markets, down to a single coin,
all things bear counterfeit’s mark.

Dongguo’s Li Yongzheng first crafted wheels and carriages,
but wearied of the toil and slow returns,
so turned to making measuring scoops and bushels.
Soon after, he took up scales and steelyards.
Within a year, those who sought deep scoops and heavy weights
he charged double and gave them what they asked.
Those who wanted to shrink a sheng to a shao,
a dou to a he,
or shave a zhu to a liang,
a liang to a jin—
he did the same.
Yongzheng also devised scales with wires twisted in midair,
scoops with split bottoms and raised beams.
The common folk, heedless of retribution,
found these convenient for daily use
and often sought them out.

One day, the Surveillance Deities reported this,
and an edict declared:
*"Those who use such things are at fault,
but those who make them are worse."*
Thus, local deities were ordered to warn them openly
and deal with them in secret.
I dispatched the local deity Duan Yanmeng to flog Yongzheng in a dream,
yet though he awoke, he did not repent.

As his reputation spread,
demand grew ever greater.
Greedy for the craft’s reward,
he worked day and night,
until his eyesight dimmed and darkened,
leaving him blind at forty.
His wife abandoned him for another,
and his two sons, born after, were also blind.

Having long plied this trade,
he was loath to abandon it at once.
With no other means of livelihood,
he used his hands as eyes,
groping for breadth,
guessing at length.
Saws, axes, nails, and drills—
he wielded them at risk,
his left hand’s five fingers
wounded by morning, maimed by night.
Scabs barely dried, flesh not yet healed,
when fresh pain struck—
fingers snapped, joints fell away,
until he could no longer grasp a tool.
Weeping, he wandered the market,
but all who knew him
showed no pity.
Hunger and cold gnawed at his bones.
Thus, for three years,
he was made to publicly confess his sins
before he died.
His two sons soon followed, starved to death.
From then on, those who had used his wares
grew somewhat more restrained.

**Ox Mountain, Fifty-Six**
Good deeds must meet their ripe reward,
While evil men encounter evil fate.
If fairness and trust bear no ill fruit,
Then cruelty and stinginess invite disaster’s weight.

Plant millet and grain, and the earth will fill,
Fear not thorns and brambles towering still.
Look to the eaves’ dripping water—
drop by drop, it falls straight,
never straying, never partial.

By the confluence of Fu and Qi Rivers in Shu,
Ox Mountain rises.
In its embrace, towns thrive,
and among their officials,
Gou Xin and Su Zhen lived as neighbors,
yet in all things stood opposed.

Xin was just and forgiving,
Zhen harsh and severe.
Xin was honest and frugal,
Zhen greedy and corrupt.
Xin was open and free,
Zhen scheming and secretive.
Xin was sincere, hiding nothing,
Zhen harbored deep grudges.
Xin’s words were trustworthy, never lightly given,
Zhen fawned and flattered, devoid of true feeling.
Xin served his mother with filial piety
and taught his son with strictness,
while Zhen disrespected his father
and indulged his wife’s insolence.
Xin sought little and spent sparingly,
Zhen squandered without restraint.
Xin harmonized with superiors and subordinates, drawing no complaints,
Zhen judged others by his own standards, granting little.
Xin covered others’ faults and spoke little,
Zhen exposed secrets and spoke much.

The townsfolk, in public and private,
deemed Xin worthy and Zhen base,
yet feared Zhen’s audacity and dared not confront him.

At year’s end, the villagers gathered for a grand feast.
Amid the wine, the elder Zhou Tong raised his hand to the crowd and said:
*"In Qin, two rivers flow—the Wei and the Jing.
One muddy, one clear,
both empty into the Yellow River.
Their sources differ,
their waves never mix.
Even a child of three,
seeing their colors,
can name them Jing and Wei,
for they are known by their clarity and turbidity.
So it is with men."*

Before he finished,
Zhen’s face and neck flushed red.
He flung his sleeves and rose, saying:
*"If Master Gou is the Wei, then I am the Jing!
Zhen and Gou Xin work together as neighbors,
and all I do, Xin knows well.
Now Xin spreads my faults,
letting the elder compare me to water before all.
I will repay Xin to make my heart clear—
Xin has never spoken of this to others!"*

From then on,
whenever Zhen saw Xin, he glared with hatred.
Though they exchanged courtesies in form,
in truth, they were enemies.
Zhen even instructed his son Mingneng
to watch for an opportunity to kill Xin’s son Yizhen.

The following spring, during the Silkworm Festival’s revelry,
Mingneng and Yizhen walked together by the river,
talking and laughing.
Mingneng harbored malice,
but Yizhen was unaware.
Relying on his strength,
he pushed Yizhen into the water.
Yizhen desperately grabbed his clothes,
and both plunged in,
bobbing amid the waves.

I was present at the feast for the river deities,
and ordered the two river dragons to rescue them.
The lords of Qi and Fu knew the boys well,
so they brought Yizhen near the shore
while turning Mingneng toward the depths.
Zhen saw this, hiked up his robes, and rushed over,
trying to push Yizhen back in.
But Yizhen pulled him in instead.
The onlookers stood like a wall,
their cries and wails rising in tumult.

Outraged, I ordered the Qi River dragon
to drag Zhen by the feet and drown him.
Yizhen emerged unharmed,
while Zhen and his son both drowned.
The crowd murmured in pairs:
*"Who says the dragons, devas, and eightfold assembly show favoritism?"*

Yet Xin and Zhen’s fortunes were not decided that day.
Xin’s good fruits had ripened,
while Zhen’s evil karma was only now fulfilled.

**Heaven’s Might, Fifty-Seven**
A woman’s nature is often partial by birth,
Yet filial devotion and earnest care are not easily complete.
Though past karma may bring the axe of thunder’s wrath,
In this life, she is blessed with the chance to serve her parents.

chunks.original_text: 亘天虐焰俄回息，卷地威风急变迁。 马氏焚尸支氏免，乃知舆议合於天。 郪邑民支祖宜，其妻喻氏，年二十五，有姑黄氏，八十病目无所见，性褊急，喜洁难事，而喻以少年勤廉恭顺，能逢迎之，三年无间言。 其夫因酒，误人仆堕两齿，求免刑责，入财自赎，以喻随赀入之，喻无悔。 一夕，梦里域追逮责曰：汝前生为比邻牟容之妻，年三十病殗楪逾年，汝之姑七十余，煮糜供汝，汝以口苦厌食，嫌其太频，哭而叱之者数四，及临死之前一日，对姑呼天曰：年七十者不死，我方三十而使之死，天不平乎！ 家司命闻之于天，帝有旨令焚汝尸，而汝气已绝，事未之行，案牍仍在，凡三十年为一世，今当结绝，汝宿业所应者，死於雷斧之下，来日俟之，以汝今生且孝，故先期告汝。 喻惊而寤，中夜坐而号泣，良人有家干出外未归，姑曰：汝以吾子破汝家赀，谓终身不可偿耶？ 喻曰无之，凌晨沐浴，新衣拜其姑曰：新妇三年事姑无状，今请假暂归，恐不测，身死不复来归，婆好将息。 姑讶其言不伦，归别其父母，所言如初。 自灶香立於屋南大木之下，仰天而祝日：新妇之死宿业当尔，有所不辞，重念夫贫姑老，晚年失妇，谁为供事，一也，父母自少小教训，今被天诛，为父母之辱，二也，身有孕已七月矣，万一得男，支氏有后，三也，今二事皆不可避，独支氏无后尔，乞少延三月分免而死。 时大暑中，阴云昼昏，风雷交至，里域为予言之，予知其心，乃为奏之，有旨：取里中凶逆者代之，富人张实妻马氏，淫悍悖逆，事姑嫜无礼，制其夫如奴隶，予即遣里域同雷火神治之，俄喻氏无恙，而实之妻焚焉。 尚义第五十八 昆义由来一父生，至亲安可便无情。 李华待蔚真堪尚，雍涤欺源太不平。 折臂舆情知显报，表闾公议得嘉名。 因令薄俗成淳厚，雁序怡怡免竞争。 土党水邑吏雍涤，有弟源亦仕于官，每为涤所窘，源以长上事之恬如也，涤源同娶梁氏二女，家私微芒必较，久之涤源为仇雠妯娌为冤对，雍之父母弗能制也，乃议析居。 欲留源之房，涤不许，俾源夫妇出一物不与，责以岁时供奉，无几路逢源，窘以不拜棰之既伤，复讼於乡大夫，请其词理，涤乃不直，涤之妻造源之门，曳乃妹出，亦棰之曰：法存长幼，终不立幼而笞长也，乡议不与之。 儒家李华父，晚景有爨婢出一子，临终嘱华曰：汝以为子，华泣对曰：是儿母虽贱，华之同气也，他日华教养之，使之成材，昭穆有序，天可质也。 厥后名之曰蔚，尤锺爱之。 既长为名士，为之娶妻，华有子弥明，先生於蔚十岁，自蔚甫能言，使弥明拜之，及长，礼待次其父一等，华与子及蔚均为乡人所举，达之太守，上之春官，论定以弥明官之，弥明失言於蔚，华乃挞之，弥明伏义，寻以家赀尽付於蔚曰：吾弟主之，弥明自有禄养矣，乡人以为贤。 秋社集，予在祭焉，乡人以雍、李相况为熏莸，涤闻之骂，坐复曳源击之，予不平焉，乃使直事紾其臂而折之，涤妻寻亦疽发于手，如此三年，公私俱废，生事寥索，父母相继而亡，涤与妻乞丐而死，乡人以为不义之报，郡守旌华之闻曰尚义。 旌隐第五十九 世情习俗最移人，日用尘劳丧本真。 守道牟君天所佑，轻身苏子鬼犹嗔。
chunks.translated_text:
The raging flames that stretched across the heavens suddenly subsided,
The fierce winds that swept the earth swiftly shifted course.
The Ma woman’s corpse was burned while the Zhi woman was spared—
Thus did public judgment align with Heaven’s decree.

In Qi County lived a man named Zhi Zuyi, whose wife, née Yu, was twenty-five. Her mother-in-law, née Huang, was eighty and blind, sharp-tempered and fastidious, difficult to serve. Yet Yu, though young, was diligent, frugal, reverent, and compliant, able to please her—three years passed without a single harsh word between them. One day, her husband, drunk, accidentally knocked over a servant, knocking out two of his teeth. To avoid punishment, he paid compensation, and Yu, following him, contributed her dowry without regret.

One night, she dreamed that a spirit from the netherworld came to arrest and reprimand her: *"In your past life, you were the wife of Mu Rong, a neighbor. At thirty, you fell gravely ill and lingered for over a year. Your mother-in-law, then over seventy, cooked porridge for you, but you, finding it bitter, refused to eat and complained of its frequency, scolding and weeping at her several times. On the day before your death, you cried out to Heaven before your mother-in-law: ‘Those over seventy do not die, yet I, at thirty, am made to perish—is Heaven unjust?’ The Director of Destinies reported this to Heaven, and the Emperor decreed that your corpse be burned. But your breath had already ceased, and the sentence was not carried out. The records remain, and after thirty years—a full cycle—your past karma must now be settled. You are fated to die beneath the axe of thunder. Tomorrow, await your fate. Yet because in this life you have been filial, I forewarn you."*

Yu awoke in terror, sitting up in the dead of night to wail. Her husband, a minor official, was away on business, and her mother-in-law said: *"You claim my son has ruined your family’s wealth—do you think you can never repay it?"* Yu replied, *"No."* At dawn, she bathed, put on fresh clothes, and bowed to her mother-in-law: *"Your daughter-in-law has served you for three years without merit. Today, I ask leave to return home briefly. I fear the unforeseen—if I die, I may not return. Mother, take care."* Her mother-in-law, bewildered by her strange words, let her go. Yu bid farewell to her parents, repeating the same words.

Standing by the kitchen incense burner beneath a great tree south of the house, she looked to Heaven and prayed: *"Your daughter-in-law’s death is the due of past karma—I do not refuse it. Yet I grieve for my poor husband and aged mother-in-law, who in their later years will lose their wife and daughter-in-law—who will care for them? First, this. Second, my parents, who raised and taught me, will be shamed by my execution. Third, I am seven months with child—if by chance it is a boy, the Zhi line will have an heir. Two of these I cannot escape, but for the sake of the Zhi line’s posterity, I beg a three-month reprieve before I die."*

It was the height of summer. Dark clouds blotted out the day, and wind and thunder clashed. The netherworld spirit later told me of this, and knowing her heart, I memorialized the matter. An edict came: *"Take a wicked and rebellious one from the village to replace her."* The wife of the wealthy Zhang Shi, née Ma, was lewd, violent, and defiant, treating her mother- and father-in-law with disrespect and reducing her husband to servitude. I dispatched the netherworld spirit and the Spirit of Thunder and Fire to deal with her. In an instant, Yu was unharmed, while Zhang’s wife was burned to ashes.

**Upholding Righteousness, Fifty-Eight**
Brothers share one father’s blood—
How can kin be heartless?
Li Hua’s care for Wei is laudable,
While Yong Di’s bullying of Yuan is unjust.
A broken arm reveals swift retribution,
Public praise earns a virtuous name.
Thus do shallow customs grow sincere,
And the geese in formation fly in harmony, free from strife.

In the town of Shuiyi, the official Yong Di had a younger brother, Yuan, also in office. Though Yuan was often oppressed by Di, he served him as an elder with equanimity. Both had married sisters from the Liang family, and even the slightest household matters became grounds for contention. Over time, Di and Yuan became enemies, their wives bitter foes. Their parents could not restrain them, so they decided to divide the household. Di refused to let Yuan keep his own quarters, forcing him and his wife to leave with nothing, yet still demanding seasonal offerings. Soon after, Di encountered Yuan on the road and, enraged that he did not bow, beat him. Wounded, Yuan sued before the village magistrate, who found Di in the wrong. Di’s wife then stormed to Yuan’s door, dragged out her sister, and beat her, saying: *"The law upholds elder and younger—one does not strike an elder for the sake of a younger!"* The village sided against her.

The Confucian scholar Li Hua’s father, in his later years, had a son by a kitchen maid. On his deathbed, he entrusted the child to Hua, saying: *"Raise him as your own."* Hua wept and replied: *"Though his mother is lowly, he is of your blood. I will teach and raise him to be worthy, and the ancestral rites will be in order—Heaven is my witness."* He named the boy Wei and doted on him. When Wei grew up, he became a renowned scholar, and Hua arranged his marriage. Hua had another son, Mimming, ten years Wei’s senior. From the time Wei could speak, Hua had Mimming bow to him. As they grew, Hua treated Wei with a respect just below that due a father. Hua, his sons, and Wei were all recommended by the villagers to the prefect, then to the capital, where their merits were assessed. The post was awarded to Mimming. When Mimming misspoke to Wei, Hua beat him. Mimming accepted the rebuke, and soon after, Hua gave all his family’s wealth to Wei, saying: *"My younger brother shall manage it. Mimming will have his official salary for support."* The villagers praised his virtue.

During the autumn festival, I attended the gathering. The villagers compared Yong and Li as the foul and the fragrant. Hearing this, Di cursed and, sitting down, dragged Yuan over to beat him. Outraged, I ordered the spirits to twist and break his arm. Soon after, Di’s wife developed an abscess on her hand. For three years, their public and private affairs collapsed, their livelihood dwindled, and their parents died in succession. Di and his wife ended as beggars. The villagers saw this as the retribution for unrighteousness. The prefect, hearing of Li Hua’s conduct, honored him as *"Upholder of Righteousness."*

**Honoring the Reclusive, Fifty-Nine**
Worldly customs most corrupt,
Daily toil in dust obscures one’s true nature.
Mu Jun, who kept to the Dao, was blessed by Heaven,
While Su Zi, who slighted his body, incurred even ghosts’ wrath.

chunks.original_text: 至言传诵为规范，庙食兴崇致奂轮。 蜀士始尊中国教，俗儒一旦变真醇。 蜀自秦并之后，中国文物之盛，先王大道之化，渐有习之者矣，而淳厚之风未振，嚣浮之徒竞起，予恐伤风教，有意欲化之。 一日，巴郡宕渠士人牟麟好学不厌，而乐於教人，守道廉退，非有大故，不出户庭，岁时起居，有受谒无出谒，贫甚而未尝怨尤，郡守温瑀辟请为从事，既不起，丞于扆往邀之，接语移时，所谈皆安时顺便，善身避世之语，扆欲致守之意而辞不得达，卒罢之，扆以告瑀，瑀嘉其节。 苏尚功者，尝学於麟，未终其业，开门受徒，以师自任，而性好奔竞，足迹不少安，求请省问，奴颜婢膝，为麟薄之，或以麟辞达之者，尚功踵门而辩之，麟亦自以为尝教诲之，犹执先觉之义而语之曰：死生有命，富贵在天，子夏之言也，求之有道，得之有命，求无益於得，子舆之言也，子之所为，吾实耻之。 尚功自恃少年拳勇击麟，予适见之，乃化一儒士，为之解纷，顾众而语之曰：人之寿夭穷达，有命在焉，非人为也，奔竞无耻，不知命者也，命之所无，求之何益，以常求之，偶有所获，以为求则得之，求益於得，是不知道者也，苟不知命且不知道，则所守既丧，放辟邪侈，至於不正不忠不孝，皆由此也，二子所为冰炭，君子小人之所以分也。 观者骈阗，或问予曰：尔为谁？ 曰：予所谓张仲子者，众惊愕相视问，予隐形不见，自是远迩闻之者，若尚功之徒改行有醇厚之风焉，渠人为予立庙。 佑正第六十 谋他财贿已非宜，况复萌心苦见欺。
chunks.translated_text:
The profound words passed down serve as moral standards,
Temples are built and sacrifices offered with grand splendor.
Scholars of Shu first revered the teachings of the Central Kingdom,
And in a single day, vulgar Confucians transformed into the truly pure.

Since Shu was annexed by Qin, the flourishing culture and teachings of the former kings and the transformative power of the great Dao gradually took root. Yet the simple and honest customs had not been revived, and the clamorous and frivolous thrived. Fearing harm to public morals, I resolved to transform them.

One day, in Ba Commandery’s Dangqu, the scholar Mou Lin was insatiable in learning and delighted in teaching others. He guarded the Dao with integrity and modesty, seldom leaving his home unless for grave matters. In his daily life, he received visitors but never paid calls himself. Though impoverished, he never uttered a word of complaint. The prefect, Wen Yu, summoned him to serve as an aide, but he declined. The assistant prefect, Yu, went to invite him in person. Their conversation lasted for hours, all on living in accord with the times, adapting to circumstances, nurturing oneself, and withdrawing from the world. Yu wished to convey the prefect’s intent but could not find the words. Finally, he left and reported to Wen Yu, who praised Mou Lin’s integrity.

Su Shanggong had once studied under Mou Lin but did not complete his studies. He opened his doors to disciples, styling himself a master, yet his nature was restless and ambitious. His footsteps never rested, and he sought favors with obsequious flattery. Mou Lin despised this. When someone relayed Mou Lin’s reproach to him, Su Shanggong rushed to his door to argue. Mou Lin, still regarding himself as his former teacher, upheld the duty of a senior and said to him: *"Life and death are a matter of fate; wealth and honor depend on Heaven."* These are the words of Zixia. *"Seek it through the proper Way, and what you obtain is a matter of fate. Seeking brings no benefit to attainment."* These are the words of Ziyu. Your conduct, I truly find shameful.

Relying on his youthful vigor, Su Shanggong struck Mou Lin. I happened to witness this and transformed into a scholar to mediate. Turning to the crowd, I said: *"Longevity or early death, poverty or success—these are matters of fate, not of human effort. Those who scramble for gain without shame do not understand fate. If fate does not grant it, what use is seeking? Even if one occasionally obtains something through persistent pursuit, to believe that seeking guarantees success is to not understand the Dao. If one neither understands fate nor the Dao, then one’s principles are lost, and from this arise depravity, deceit, and all manner of unrighteousness—disloyalty, unfiliality, and worse. The conduct of these two men is as incompatible as ice and fire, marking the division between the noble and the petty."*

The onlookers gathered in a throng. Someone asked me: *"Who are you?"* I replied: *"I am the one called Zhang Zhongzi."* The crowd stared in astonishment, and when they looked again, I had vanished without a trace. From then on, those near and far who heard of this—even men like Su Shanggong—reformed their ways, and a pure and honest custom flourished. The people of Dangqu built a temple for me.

**Upholding Rectitude, Sixty**
To scheme for others’ wealth is already improper,
How much worse to harbor deceitful intentions.

"Let a righteous woman’s single plea invoke retribution,
And good folk, their whole household, escape ruin’s snare.
Suddenly, their bonds fall away from their limbs,
While the cruel and violent are soon torn limb from limb.
Blessing the good and punishing the wicked—such is Heaven’s principle;
Not I who receive their offerings repay their private debts.

In the Northern Capital lived a wealthy household, Zhi Jinli,
Who, in mid-spring, performed the rites.
His entire household grew drunk,
When a bandit named Wang Cai, with three accomplices,
Plotted to rob them.
That night, before the hour had waned, they forced the door open,
Binding Jinli’s family—nine in all, men and women, free and servile—
Along with seven maidservants and concubines.
Only Jinli’s wife and two daughters, Rong and her sisters, were left unbound.
After seizing their wealth, the bandits sought to violate them.
Jinli’s wife, trembling with fear, begged for mercy.
The younger daughter, Shunhua, aged fifteen,
Clung to her mother with her sister Shunying, weeping.
As Cai moved to force himself upon them, Hua cursed him:
‘Starving thief, you dare violate my home—
Does the Divine Lord Zhang not yet know of you?’

At these words, the household’s Controller of Destinies, Cui Xuan,
Along with Zhi’s ancestor, Mi, urgently appealed to me.
I dispatched the Merit Officer Fu Xing,
Leading a hundred soldiers of the unseen realm to intervene.
The ropes binding Jinli and the others fell away of their own accord,
And all the bandits were seized.
The next day, the matter was reported to the village head,
Then to the commandery—
All were executed.

chunks.original_text: 杀生第六十一 蠢动含灵皆有命，贪生畏死与人同。 因思骨髓脂膏味，俾在砧刀鼎镬中。 不顾冤魂随影响，只知滋味美喉咙。 杜章享尽前生福，业果成时报不空。 邛有杜章，望帝之支也，生於富贵，父母好宴乐，会集以为常，凡烹割之事，章躬亲之，及长，身任门户厨撰无虚日，脍炙方离口，刀杌已在手矣。 后以灾祸相继，家道零替，无以为生，为人屠刽以就口食，所取人财名过命钱，又以饮啖兼人，饕餮成疾，方且饱满，寻复中虚，而性嗜肉味，日常不足，及以罟取鱼，以弋弹雀，所见飞走，皆萌杀心。 中年生五子皆无指，口累所迫，过命之赀，不足度日，凄惶无聊，寻有癞疾，肌肤破裂，脓血流溃，见者掩鼻矣。 自以饥火所烧，复受疾苦，投井自尽，为人执之，极口辱骂，於是仰天呼冤。 予见之，讶而问里域主者、孙洪 叔言其详，且言此人禄尽而命长，尚余五年，予既知其造业之由，又复闵其受苦之酷，且岁方遥，恶其日夕怨怒天帝，乃遣功曹易其心志，使以手揭疮皮以自食之，又以指点脓血吮咀求味，宣言於人哕； 毋作杀生业，以我为戒，如此逾年，以准未尽之数，念断而死，诸子皆殍焉。 酷虐第六十二 公孙武仲处心廉，鞭挞诸胥失大严。 资水赖恩还纵吏，酷民诛取却无厌。 化身戒励诚惟一，改行宽平利可兼。 栽抑有余增不足，吏民两邑惠俱沾。 牛鞞邑令公孙武仲治己以廉，而待人不恕，左右之人小有过失，笞一二百，莅邑逾年，而胥吏无全肤，吏怨之。 资水邑令赖恩性贪沓以苞苴为常，日用饮食，岁时衣装，取给於胥吏，而民事造庭者，无问曲直，悉付之狴讦，恣吏诛求，意足乃已，吏意未厌，则迁延岁月，置而不问，民怨之。 予以二邑之吏民被苦，乃化身为蜀郡丞长孙义，行诸邑观风俗，劾仲之虐吏，赖恩之酷民，二令叩头乞免，予戒励之，寻隐而不现。 后知郡丞初无行邑之事，二邑成以为神而敬信之，武仲改而忠恕，恩亦变而廉洁焉。 悯世第六十三 周室隳颓为不仁，苍姬一旦变嬴秦。 惨刑暴吏无和气，诈计穷兵又几春。 不忍中原罹此祸，愿开方寸济斯民。 上天有旨垂俞允，雨后乾坤又一新。 予尝仕於周，以忠尽命，血食於蜀，未几，蜀入於秦，已而周丧天下，皆嬴氏矣。 秦任刑法，视民如草芥，秦衰而干戈又起，中原涂炭于斯久矣。 予以久处静境，思以拯斯民之苦，乃飞章上闻于帝，从之，若曰：白帝子游人间久矣，而暴於杀伐，今已遣赤帝子代之矣，汝以本司火德，今当应世，以为赤帝子之后，予受命焉。 咸阳第六十四 护持全蜀幸优游，应世情牵强出头。 被谮不成膺继统，杀身空与结冤雠。 封王缘薄终何益，报母心酸未肯休。 那得身为率然相，尽吞诸吕快幽忧。 予之恳于上天，将以化身援天下於涂炭之中，跻斯民於和乐之地，无何，帝命以予为赤帝子之后，玉音可畏，予不敢抗，静而思之，非所望也。 俄有九天监生大神，逼予受生，於云霄间下视咸阳火秦之后宫阙鼎新，汉帝方与戚姬昭语，监生逼予曰：此所谓赤帝子者也，今为汉帝矣，予纵目间，为监生大神所挤，堕於帝侧戚姬之怀，恍然而觉。 帝以予生骨相相肖举止可喜，名予曰如意，予虽提孩中，而本志尚坚，语言顾盻尤惬帝意，帝尤锺爱，每以予兄为不类，薄之，晚年欲以予为太子，既不果，帝万岁后，卒为吕氏所杀，予母之死，尤被酷毒，予深怨之，方冥冥间见母受苦时，思得复为率然之相，尽吞诸吕而后已也。
chunks.translated_text:
**On Killing Living Beings (Chapter Sixty-One)**
All creatures that move and breathe possess fate,
Fearing death and craving life as men do too.
Yet for the taste of marrow, fat, and flesh,
They cast them onto cleavers, cauldrons, and flames.
Heedless of vengeful souls that trail like shadows,
They know only the savor that pleases the throat.
Du Zhang enjoyed the fortune of past lives,
But when karmic retribution came, it was not in vain.

In Qiong there lived Du Zhang, a descendant of King Wang of Shu. Born into wealth and nobility, his parents indulged in feasting and revelry as their custom. Every act of butchery and carving, Zhang performed himself. As he grew, he took charge of the household’s kitchen, never a day passing without his hand wielding the knife. No sooner had the roasted meat left his lips than the chopping block was already in his grasp.

Later, misfortune struck in succession, and his family’s fortunes declined. Left with no means of survival, he became a butcher and executioner to feed himself. The wealth he took from others was called "life-money," exceeding its due. His gluttony grew insatiable, and his voracious appetite bred illness. No sooner was he full than hunger returned, yet his craving for meat remained unchecked. Daily, he fell short of his desires. He cast nets to catch fish, used slings to shoot birds, and whatever flew or ran before him stirred his murderous intent.

In middle age, he fathered five sons, all born without fingers. Pressed by debt and the burden of "life-money," he could not make ends meet. Desperate and forlorn, he contracted a loathsome disease—his skin split open, oozing pus and blood, so foul that passersby covered their noses.

Tormented by hunger’s fire and afflicted by suffering, he threw himself into a well, only to be dragged out and cursed vehemently. Then, gazing heavenward, he cried out in grievance.

I witnessed this and, astonished, questioned Sun Hong, the local domain master, who recounted the details. He added that though Du Zhang’s allotted years had ended, his life still had five years remaining. Knowing the cause of his karmic deeds and pitying the severity of his suffering—yet with many years still ahead—I feared his daily resentment and anger toward the Celestial Emperor. Thus, I dispatched a Merit Officer to alter his heart and will. He was made to peel the scabs from his own sores and eat them, to dip his fingers into pus and blood, sucking and savoring the taste, then declare to others: *"Do not commit the sin of killing—take me as your warning!"*

Thus, for over a year, he endured until his allotted time was fulfilled. His breath ceased, and all his sons perished as well.

---

**On Cruelty (Chapter Sixty-Two)**
Gongsun Wuzhong governed with integrity,
Yet his floggings of clerks lacked true severity.
Lai En, by grace, released his subordinates,
But his rapacity toward the people knew no end.
A transformed self served as the sole admonition,
A change to leniency brought dual benefit.
Curbing excess to supplement deficiency,
Both clerks and commoners reaped the blessing.

The magistrate of Niu Bing County, Gongsun Wuzhong, ruled himself with incorruptibility but treated others without mercy. The slightest fault in his subordinates earned them one or two hundred lashes. After a year in office, not a single clerk remained unscarred, and they resented him bitterly.

The magistrate of Zi Shui County, Lai En, was by nature greedy and habitually accepted bribes. His daily food and drink, seasonal clothing, and adornments were all supplied by his clerks. When commoners came to his court, regardless of right or wrong, he consigned them to prison, allowing his clerks to extort them at will. Only when his desires were sated would he act; if the clerks remained unsatisfied, he would delay for months or even abandon the case entirely. The people despised him.

I saw the suffering of the clerks and commoners in these two counties and transformed myself into Changsun Yi, the assistant prefect of Shu Commandery. I toured the counties to observe their customs and impeached Wuzhong for his cruelty to clerks and Lai En for his oppression of the people. Both magistrates kowtowed, begging for mercy. I admonished and exhorted them, then vanished without a trace.

Later, they learned that the assistant prefect had never visited the counties. Both counties came to revere me as a divine being, and Wuzhong reformed, governing with loyalty and forbearance, while Lai En also transformed, becoming incorrupt and upright.

---

**On Pitying the World (Chapter Sixty-Three)**
The House of Zhou collapsed into inhumanity,
As the Ji clan’s rule gave way to Qin’s tyranny.
Harsh punishments and brutal clerks stifled harmony,
Deceitful schemes and endless wars—how many springs?
Unable to bear the Central Plains’ suffering,
I wished to open my heart to save its people.
Heaven’s decree granted assent,
And after the storm, the world was renewed.

I once served the Zhou, offering loyalty unto death, and received sacrifices in Shu. Before long, Shu fell to Qin, and soon after, the Zhou lost the realm—all to the House of Ying.

Qin relied on harsh laws, treating the people as grass and weeds. When Qin declined, warfare erupted anew, and the Central Plains suffered in devastation for years.

Having long dwelled in tranquility, I yearned to relieve the people’s suffering. Thus, I submitted a memorial to the Celestial Emperor, who granted my request, saying: *"The son of the White Emperor has wandered the mortal realm for too long, steeped in slaughter. Now, I have sent the son of the Red Emperor to replace him. You, as the original minister of Fire Virtue, shall now respond to the world as the successor to the Red Emperor’s son."* I accepted the mandate.

---

**On Xianyang (Chapter Sixty-Four)**
Fortune favored my protection of all Shu,
Yet worldly ties compelled me to emerge.
Slander thwarted my succession,
And my death left only enmity.
A king’s title, thin as fate, brought no gain,
While my mother’s bitter suffering never ceased.
How I longed to take the form of a *shuairan*,
To devour the Lü clan and end my sorrow!

My plea to Heaven had been to transform myself and lift the world from its suffering, guiding its people to harmony and joy. Unexpectedly, the Emperor decreed that I should succeed the son of the Red Emperor. The Jade Edict inspired awe, and I dared not refuse. Reflecting in stillness, I knew this was not my desire.

Suddenly, the Great Deity of the Nine Heavens’ Surveillance pressed me to be reborn. From the clouds, I gazed down upon the newly built palaces of Xianyang, where the Fire-Qin’s successor now ruled. The Han Emperor was conversing with Lady Qi Zhao. The surveillance deity urged me: *"This is the so-called son of the Red Emperor—now the Han Emperor."* As I looked on, the deity forced me forward, and I tumbled into Lady Qi’s embrace. In a daze, I awoke.

The Emperor, seeing my birthmarks and bearing, found me delightful and named me Ruyi. Though still an infant, my original resolve remained firm. My speech and glances pleased the Emperor greatly, and he doted on me, often calling my elder brother unlike him and treating him with disdain. In his later years, he wished to make me his heir, but it did not come to pass. After the Emperor’s death, I was ultimately killed by the Lü clan. My mother’s end was even more cruel, and I harbored deep resentment.

When I later saw her suffering in the netherworld, I longed to take the form of a *shuairan* and devour the Lü clan to the last.

chunks.original_text: 邛池第六十五 恃势凌人不可为，无辜母子被诛夷。 衔冤入地至极矣，不共戴天良是之。 诸吕后身同一邑，双亲乞命在斯时。 海波平陷四十里，还我当年受百罹。 予自罹吕祸之后，神游冥漠，又无职守，尝蓄宿愤，思欲报之，已往修积，不复问焉。 虽诸吕死拘幽冥，造业深重，历年甚多，逮再生亦久，遂访西海之滨，有邑名邛池，邑令吕牟，吕后之后身也，邑人多吕氏，盖宿业相寻，诸吕造业之党也，萃於穷荒。 予母夫人亦生於彼，复为戚氏，以前身享福太过，生此而贫悴，所嫁张子，年老无嗣，夫妇以芟刈为业，一日野外相顾而语曰：生身窘甚，辛苦自养，暮年力衰，将不兔於沟壑，今六十而无子，是天将杀之耶？ 乃相与割臂出血，沥於石凹中，以石覆之，拜天而祝曰：人皆有子，惟我独无，今气血薄少，不能施化，愿此石下倘使动物生焉，亦遗体也，予识母氏心倦倦焉，一念感之，从而寓止。 明日二老复来，揭石视之，血化为蛇，金色寸长，予所为也，母收养之，逾年，顶上出角，腹下生足，能自变化，每天欲雨，予为助之，身既长大，腹量宽迈，见羊豕犬马辄食之，邑令有马，色洁而骏，牧於水际，蹄伤吾末，因拘而啖之，马盖吕产之报身也。 邑人皆知予，详访於予家而不获，逮予父母於囹圄，责以三日求予，无状将见杀焉，次日，予化儒士谒令解之，令曰：张老夫妇家养妖蛇，食人六畜久矣，今又食吾马，吾将杀之，为民去害，张不见听，是彼自为妖也，今必戮之。 予曰：物命相偿，宿业所致，遇彼吞噬，亦非偶然，今君为畜而杀人，岂令尹之事乎？ 令叱予使退，予复语之曰：君有死气浮於面颜，宜善自爱，他日无悔。 语毕，予隐形不见，令之左右皆以予为妖，予乃奏天称冤，陈以前世子母无辜死於诸吕，今适逢之，愿与之较，辞上而未报。 因变化风雷，呼吸云雾，白昼而暝，一邑之人，相视而语曰：汝头那得为鱼，至以手相扪头面而泣，一夕扬海水以为雨，灌注城邑，围四十里皆陷，予以身载父母而出焉，时孝宣之世，今所谓陷河者是也。 解脱第六十六 嗔恚之心莫易生，此心生处是无明。 只知直理堪平诉，不待琅音辄径行。 谪受大身遭热恼，填还冤债慰群情。 世尊一语消余业，却得当来面目成。 予前以吕氏冤对，奏帝未报而擅行之，虽一时快意，宿愦顿消，及心定意平，良用深悔。 翌日玉音荐降，以海神晁闳劾予擅用海水，陷溺平民五百余户，以口计之，二千余命，除里域所具予前身仇对八十余人，半在城隍，半居附郭外，其余生齿，皆系夭枉，帝命赐谴以予为邛池龙，而夺其神职，且使天吏监临，不得予预雨泽，羁囚於积水之下，连年旱虐，水复为泥，身既广大，无穴可容，烈日上临，内外热恼，八万四千诸鳞甲中，各生小虫，师嗜不已，宛转困苦，不记春秋。 一日晨凉，天光忽开五色云气，浮空而过，中有瑞相，钳发螺旋，金容月莹，现诸胜妙，希有光明，山灵河伯，万众稽首，赞叹欢喜，声动天地，复有天香缭绕四合，天花纷委，随处生春，予乃耳目聪明，鼻观通彻，心清口润，声音发扬，仰首哀号，乞垂救度。 万灵诸圣诚卫先后，咸谓予曰：此西方大圣正觉世尊释迦文佛也，今以教法流行东土，随教化身，将往中国，尔既遭逢，宿业可脱，予遂起改悔心，生悲愍念，身自踊跃入天光中，具陈往昔报应之理。

**Lake Qiong, Sixty-Fifth**

To rely on power and bully others is never to be done—
An innocent mother and child were put to death.
The grievance I bore sank deep into the earth,
A hatred so profound it could not share the sky.
The Lü clan’s later lives dwelt in the same town,
Their parents begging for mercy in that very hour.
The sea’s waves leveled forty *li* of land,
Repaying all the hundred sorrows I once endured.

After suffering the Lü clan’s calamity, my spirit wandered the netherworld, unbound by any office. I harbored long-held resentment and yearned for vengeance, yet my past deeds of cultivation had faded from concern. Though the Lü clan had died and been confined to the dark realms, their karmic burden ran deep, spanning many years. Even after their rebirths, much time had passed. I sought them along the western sea’s shores, where a town named Qiong lay. Its magistrate, Lü Mou, was the Lü empress’s later incarnation, and many of its people bore the Lü surname—old karmic ties drawing them together, the Lü clan’s accomplices, now gathered in this desolate land.

My mother, the Lady, was also reborn there, once more as a Qi. Having enjoyed excessive fortune in her past life, she was now poor and emaciated. She married a man named Zhang, old and childless. The couple lived by cutting grass. One day, they spoke to each other in the wilds: *"Our lives are so straitened, we toil to sustain ourselves. Now, in our twilight years, our strength wanes—we shall surely perish in some ditch. Sixty years old and still without a child—does Heaven mean to destroy us?"* They cut their arms and let blood drip into a stone’s hollow, covering it with the rock. Kneeling to Heaven, they prayed: *"All others have children; only we are barren. Our qi and blood are meager, unable to nurture life. If some creature should stir beneath this stone, let it be born of our flesh."* I sensed my mother’s earnest longing, and moved by her plea, I took form there.

The next day, the old couple returned and lifted the stone. The blood had transformed into a golden snake, a hand’s span in length—my doing. My mother took me in and raised me. A year later, horns sprouted from my head, and legs grew beneath my belly. I could change my form at will. Whenever rain threatened, I aided the skies. As I grew, my body expanded, my appetite vast. I devoured sheep, pigs, dogs, and horses on sight. The magistrate owned a fine, swift horse, grazing by the water. Its hoof injured my tail, so I seized and ate it—the horse was Lü Chan’s later incarnation.

The townsfolk knew of me. They searched my home in vain, then imprisoned my parents, demanding they produce me within three days or face execution. The next day, I transformed into a scholar and petitioned the magistrate for their release. He said: *"The old Zhangs keep a demonic snake that has long preyed on livestock. Now it has eaten my horse. I will kill it to rid the people of this scourge."* When the Zhangs were not heeded, he declared: *"They have become demons themselves. They must die."*

I replied: *"Life repays life—this is the work of past karma. Their devouring was no accident. If you, as a magistrate, kill humans for the sake of an animal, is this justice?"* The magistrate shouted for me to withdraw. I pressed on: *"Your face bears the mark of death. Take care for yourself, lest you regret it later."* With that, I vanished. The magistrate’s attendants called me a demon. I then appealed to Heaven, recounting how my mother and I had been wrongly slain by the Lü clan in a past life, and how I had now encountered them again. I vowed to settle the score. My plea ascended, but no reply came.

I summoned wind and thunder, inhaled clouds and mist, turning day to night. The townsfolk stared at one another, saying: *"Why does your head look like a fish?"* They touched their faces and wept. That night, I raised the sea’s waters as rain, flooding the town. Forty *li* of land sank. I bore my parents to safety on my back. This occurred in the reign of Emperor Xiaoxuan—what is now called the Sunken River.

**Liberation, Sixty-Sixth**

The heart’s wrath arises all too easily,
And where it stirs, ignorance takes root.
One knows the truth is plain enough to plead,
Yet without waiting for decree, one acts.
Exiled to a massive form, scorched by heat,
Repaying karmic debts to soothe the wronged.
A single word from the World-Honored One
Dissolves my lingering karma—my true face restored.

In my earlier confrontation with the Lü clan, I had petitioned the Emperor but received no reply, so I took matters into my own hands. Though my long-held rage was vented in that moment, when my heart settled and my mind grew calm, deep regret took hold. The next day, a jade decree descended: the Sea God Chao Hong had accused me of misusing the sea’s waters, drowning over five hundred households—more than two thousand lives. Excluding the eighty-odd souls who had been my past-life enemies (half in the city god’s precinct, half in the outskirts), the rest were innocent, cut down before their time. The Emperor commanded that I be demoted to the dragon of Lake Qiong, stripped of my divine office, and placed under celestial overseers. I was forbidden to partake in rainmaking, imprisoned beneath stagnant waters. Years of drought followed, and the water turned to mud. My vast body had no burrow to shelter in. The scorching sun beat down, tormenting me inside and out. From my eighty-four thousand scales, countless tiny worms emerged, gnawing without end. I writhed in agony, losing track of the seasons.

One morning, as a cool breeze stirred, the sky suddenly parted, revealing five-colored clouds drifting past. Within them appeared an auspicious sign: coiled hair bound in a topknot, a golden countenance like the moon, wondrous and rare, radiant with light. Mountain spirits and river lords, myriad beings bowed in reverence, their voices of praise and joy shaking heaven and earth. Heavenly incense curled through the air, celestial blossoms scattered, and spring bloomed wherever they fell. My ears and eyes grew sharp, my nose keen, my heart clear, my mouth moist, my voice resonant. I lifted my head and wailed, begging for deliverance.

The host of sacred beings before and behind me spoke: *"This is the World-Honored One, the Tathāgata Śākyamuni Buddha, the Perfectly Awakened One of the West. His teachings now spread through the Eastern Lands. He takes form to teach and transform, journeying to the Middle Kingdom. Since you have encountered him, your past karma may be dissolved."* Stirred by remorse and compassion, I leapt into the divine light and recounted the principles of karmic retribution from my past.

chunks.original_text: 世尊答言：善哉帝子，汝於向来孝家忠国，作大饶益，又复悯世生护持心，因果未周，仇敌相争，以人我想肆兴残忍，迁怒于物，业债当偿，今复自悔，欲求解脱，汝於此时，复有前生冤亲之想，与夫嗔恚愚痴念否？ 予闻至理，心地开明，内外罄然如虚空，住无人无我，诸念顿息，自顾其身，随念消灭，复为男子，听佛宣说，得灌顶智，得大辩才，得神通力，得圆满相，龙天八部皆大欣悦予皈依焉。 仁政第六十七 嗔业焚和障最深，坚持忍铠莫容侵。 疮伤尔体犹吾体，痛切他心似我心。 吏既不欺终干蛊，民知相爱自甘临。 清河薄誉缘斯得，歌咏惟将和舜琴。
chunks.translated_text:
The World-Honored One replied: *"Excellent, Prince! In your past, you were filial to your family and loyal to your kingdom, bringing great benefit. Moreover, you pitied the world and nurtured a heart of protection. Yet the cycle of cause and effect was not yet complete—enemies still contended, and through the delusion of self and others, cruelty ran rampant. You vented your wrath upon all things, and the karmic debt must be repaid. Now, having repented and seeking liberation, do you still harbor thoughts of past-life enemies and loved ones? Do anger, ignorance, and delusion linger?"*

Hearing this profound truth, my mind opened like the sky—inner and outer emptied as if into boundless space. Abiding in no-self and no-other, all thoughts ceased. I beheld my form, and with each念, it dissolved. Reborn as a man, I listened as the Buddha expounded the Dharma, receiving the wisdom of abhiṣeka, the eloquence of great discernment, the power of divine transformation, and the perfection of marks. The Eight Divisions of Dragons and Devas rejoiced greatly, and I took refuge in them.

**Virtuous Governance, Sixty-Seventh**
The fire of wrath burns deepest, barring harmony—
hold fast to the armor of patience, let none breach it.
Wounds on your body are wounds on mine;
another’s pain cuts as deeply as my own.
Officials who deceive will surely fall to corruption,
while people who love one another willingly submit.
The clear river’s modest renown flows from this—
its songs of praise harmonize with the lute of Shun.

g for deliverance.

The host of sacred beings before and behind me spoke: *"This is the World-Honored One, the Tathāgata Śākyamuni Buddha, the Perfectly Awakened One of the West. His teachings now spread through the Eastern Lands. He takes form to teach and transform, journeying to the Middle Kingdom. Since you have encountered him, your past karma may be dissolved."* Stirred by remorse and compassion, I leapt into the divine light and recounted the principles of karmic retribution from my past.
